channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Kremlin watches Trump as Russia and Ukraine hold a third round of ceasefire talks
item.description: The latest talks could be an early litmus test on how seriously Moscow perceives President Trump's threats to impose sanctions — and how Russia might respond.
item.content:encoded:
The latest talks could be an early litmus test on how seriously Moscow perceives President Trump's threats to impose sanctions — and how Russia might respond.

(Image credit: Michael Shtekel)
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: GOP divided over Epstein files. And, Columbia disciplines student protesters
item.description: The GOP is divided over whether they want more details released about the Jeffrey Epstein federal investigations. And, over 70 Columbia University students have been disciplined for protests.
item.content:encoded:
The GOP is divided over whether they want more details released about the Jeffrey Epstein federal investigations. And, over 70 Columbia University students have been disciplined for protests.

(Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: How China came to rule the world of rare earth elements
item.description: The U.S. once controlled the market on rare earth elements, sought after for a range of technologies. But in the last few decades, China has cornered that market and surpassed the U.S.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. once controlled the market on rare earth elements, sought after for a range of technologies. But in the last few decades, China has cornered that market and surpassed the U.S.

(Image credit: DigitalGlobe)
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: U.S. probes foreign links to agriculture research to protect food supply
item.description: While researchers agree food security is important, they say scrutiny of foreign collaboration could hurt U.S. innovation.
item.content:encoded:
While researchers agree food security is important, they say scrutiny of foreign collaboration could hurt U.S. innovation.

(Image credit: Jim Watson)
item.dc:creator: Ximena Bustillo

item.title: What's it like to have Frank Lloyd Wright design your house? This 101-year-old knows
item.description: Roland Reisley is the last original client of Frank Lloyd Wright, still living in the Usonian home designed by the famed architect. Even after 73 years, he told NPR, he still marvels at the beauty of the home.
item.content:encoded:
Roland Reisley is the last original client of Frank Lloyd Wright, still living in the Usonian home designed by the famed architect. Even after 73 years, he told NPR, he still marvels at the beauty of the home.

(Image credit: Keren Carrión)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: How effective is 'precooling' your home during off-peak hours? It depends
item.description: Does precooling your home work? Yes, no or maybe — depending on who you ask. But don't worry, we also have some other tips to keep you cool this summer.
item.content:encoded:
Does precooling your home work? Yes, no or maybe — depending on who you ask. But don't worry, we also have some other tips to keep you cool this summer.

(Image credit: George Frey)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: Protests are near constant. Do they work?
item.description: To the casual observer, it might seem like the U.S. has been spent years in a constant state of protest, from the Women's March in 2017 to the racial uprisings in 2020 to the No Kings protests earlier in the summer. But some are starting to wonder: How effective are any of those protests? When it comes to achieving lasting social change, do any of them work?
item.content:encoded: To the casual observer, it might seem like the U.S. has been spent years in a constant state of protest, from the Women's March in 2017 to the racial uprisings in 2020 to the No Kings protests earlier in the summer. But some are starting to wonder: How effective are any of those protests? When it comes to achieving lasting social change, do any of them work?
item.dc:creator: B.A. Parker

item.title: The U.N.'s highest court will decide on the climate obligations of countries
item.description: After years of lobbying by vulnerable island nations, the U.N. asked the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion, a non-binding but important basis for international obligations.
item.content:encoded:
After years of lobbying by vulnerable island nations, the U.N. asked the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion, a non-binding but important basis for international obligations.

(Image credit: Annika Hammerschlag)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Thousands protest as Zelenskyy signs bill weakening anti-corruption agencies
item.description: Ukraine's parliament passed legislation that will tighten oversight of two key anti-corruption agencies, which critics say could significantly weaken their independence.
item.content:encoded:
Ukraine's parliament passed legislation that will tighten oversight of two key anti-corruption agencies, which critics say could significantly weaken their independence.

(Image credit: Alex Babenko)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Trump announces trade deal with Japan that lowers threatened tariff to 15%
item.description: The 15% tax on imported Japanese goods is a meaningful drop from the 25% rate that Trump, in a recent letter to Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, said would be levied starting Aug. 1.
item.content:encoded:
The 15% tax on imported Japanese goods is a meaningful drop from the 25% rate that Trump, in a recent letter to Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, said would be levied starting Aug. 1.

(Image credit: Shuji Kajiyama)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
